awd_titl_txt: Arabidopsis 2010:   Analysis of the Cytokinin-Regulated Transcriptional Network
awd_abstract_narration: Cytokinins are plant hormones that affect a diverse array of plant growth and development processes. How cytokinins mediate such a diverse array of processes remains a fundamental question in plant biology with important agricultural implications. In this project, genetic, molecular, and genomic approaches will be used to identify and characterize the critical factors that control gene expression in response to cytokinin. Computational approaches will then be used to build a network of cytokinin-regulated gene expression. These data will be incorporated into a database available through the project website (http://www.bio.unc.edu/research/two-component/default.htm) so that the research community can easily view and make use of the regulatory network. Results from the proposed research will benefit society through the elucidation of a critical gene network that regulates multiple traits of agronomic importance. Previous work suggests that results from the project will provide avenues to modify agriculturally relevant traits such as grain yield, energy capture and use, senescence, responses to environmental stresses, and patterns of growth and development. The proposed research will enhance the infrastructure of research and education by providing training for undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers, as well as the creation and maintenance of programs aimed at fostering science education in grades K-12.

por.por_cntn:
One of the hallmark features of plant hormones is their pleiotropic nature. Cytokinins, like other plant hormones, affect a diverse array of plant growth and development processes and responses to the environment. How a signaling molecule mediates such a diverse array of outputs and how these response pathway are integrated with other inputs remains a fundamental question in plant biology. This grant focused on dissecting the mechanisms by which the plant hormone cytokinin mediates these diverse outputs. To this end, we employed a variety of integrative approaches to characterize the transcriptional network that mediates the cytokinin response. We delineated the changes in the transcriptome that occur in response to cytokinin and characterized transcription factors that modulate gene expression in response to cytokinin. These transcription factors included the type-B ARRs, which are master regulators of cytokinin-mediated gene expression, the CRF and GNC/CGA1 families of transcription factors, which influence a subset of cytokinin-regulated genes, as well as additional transcription factors that influence cytokinin responsiveness. We found that the type-B ARRs bind to target genes in a cytokinin-dependent manner, identified motifs involved in their binding, and performed a genome-wide analysis to identify their direct targets. We also identified a novel family of proteins that regulate degradation of the type-B ARRs, and therefore cytokinin sensitivity in the plant. Systems analysis approaches making use of these datasets point to sub-networks of genes that mediate hormonal crosstalk with cytokinin to control growth and development, as well as to how cytokinin mediates responses to biotic and abiotic stimuli.

      By analyzing Arabidopsis lines disrupted for various signaling elements, we defined mechanisms that regulate specific responses to cytokinin. We characterized mechanisms by which cytokinin controls aspects of growth and development. These include defining regulatory networks involving cross-talk of cytokinin with auxin and ethylene to control root cell proliferation and elongation as well as inhibition of cell division of the root quiescent center, which is an organizing center in the root stem cell niche. In addition, we characterized roles for cytokinin in regulating development of the female gametophyte and in regulating chloroplast development and senescence through activation of specific families of transcription factors. We also characterized mechanisms by which cytokinin mediates responses to biotic and abiotic stimuli. For biotic stimuli, we demonstrated a key role for cytokinin in the proliferation of several pathogens, including plant parasitic nematodes and downy mildew. Our results suggest that pathogens must maintain a balance between elevating cytokinin function sufficiently to promote their optimal growth, but below levels that would trigger a strong plant defense response. For abiotic stimuli, we determined that cytokinin regulates sodium accumulation and the salt stress response due to transcriptional regulation of a key sodium transporter. Taken together, these studies have substantially increased our understanding of cytokinin function in higher plants, and establish a foundation for its manipulation to improve plant performance in agricultural settings.

     This grant enabled the training of undergraduates, Ph.D. students, and postdoctoral fellows. It also supported two Workshops in Next-Generation Sequencing (WiNGS) that provided researchers, educators, and students from a variety of backgrounds (80 and 100 participants per year) with theoretical background and hands-on experience with new methods for analyzing high-throughput genomic data.
